content.title: Below-Knee Amputation (Transtibial Amputation)
content.description: Major lower extremity amputation through the tibia and fibula, preserving the knee joint for optimal functional rehabilitation.
content.definition: Below-knee amputation (BKA) or transtibial amputation removes the lower leg while preserving the knee joint. Preferred over above-knee amputation when healing potential exists, as knee preservation dramatically improves prosthetic ambulation and energy expenditure.

surgical_technique: Beveled anterior tibial cortex to prevent skin pressure
Myodesis or myoplasty for muscle stabilization
level_selection_criteria: Palpable popliteal pulse strongly favors healing
functional_outcomes: 70% of BKA patients achieve prosthetic ambulation
Much lower than AKA (80-100% above normal)
Quality of life significantly better than AKA

clinical_pearls: Preserve knee whenever possible - 70% BKA vs 30% AKA will walk
Long posterior flap provides well-vascularized soft tissue coverage
Minimum 12cm residual limb for prosthetic fitting
Gastrocnemius muscle provides cushion for tibial end
Rigid dressing or immediate postop prosthesis reduces edema
